statements: Policing should be guided by a dual commitment to protecting public safety and upholding civil rights, recognizing that communities need both effective crime prevention and fair, respectful treatment. A practical middle ground is to pair targeted, evidence-based enforcement and rapid response to serious violence with strong guardrails—clear use-of-force standards, de-escalation training, transparent data reporting, independent oversight, and accountability when rights are violated. Building trust through community partnerships and problem-solving, while measuring outcomes like reduced harm, fewer unnecessary stops, and improved legitimacy, can help bridge differing views on how policing should work.
